Inference: Freeze-induced leak identification
Description: Leaks that occur shortly after pipe temperatures drop below a freeze threshold are likely caused by freezing and ice expansion, identified by aligning leak timestamps with sub-freezing temperature readings in the same segment.
short rationale: Event-specific alignment with temperature; high reconstruction of incident timing/location.

Inference: Thermal-stress leak zones
Description: Locations that show both frequent leaks and large daily or seasonal temperature swings are hotspots where repeated expansion and contraction likely weaken joints or pipe walls.
short rationale: Maps vulnerable zones with history; notable location sensitivity.

Inference: Empirical freeze danger threshold
Description: The temperatures observed just before freeze-related leaks define a system-specific danger band, improving on a generic 0°C rule for freeze warnings.
short rationale: Derives thresholds from incidents; moderate sensitivity with minimal personal data.

Inference: Seasonal leak risk modeling from temperature–leak correlation
Description: Higher leak rates during periods when average pipe temperatures are low indicate cold-driven seasonal leak risk that can be forecast from historical leak–temperature patterns.
short rationale: Seasonal risk profiles; aggregated but reveals patterns over time.

Inference: Non-thermal leak classification
Description: Leaks that consistently occur when temperatures are moderate and stable are likely due to mechanical wear, pressure, or installation defects rather than thermal effects.
short rationale: Cause classification; low personal exposure.

Inference: Cold-spot leak vulnerability mapping
Description: Sensors that repeatedly record the lowest temperatures and also have more leak events mark structural cold spots that are prime targets for additional insulation or rerouting.
short rationale: Identifies cold spots with leak history; location/layout sensitive.

Inference: Effectiveness of insulation upgrades
Description: Comparing leak frequency and temperature profiles before and after insulation at the same locations reveals whether the upgrades reduced freeze-related leaks at similar low temperatures.
short rationale: Pre/post comparison by location; moderate sensitivity.

Inference: Hot-water fatigue leaks
Description: Leak events clustering on lines where temperature remains frequently high suggest heat-induced material fatigue in hot-water pipes or near heaters.
short rationale: Hot-line stress identification; moderate location/system exposure.

Inference: Time-lag between cold exposure and leak
Description: Leaks that occur hours or days after pipes warm up from sub-freezing levels indicate delayed failures stemming from earlier freeze damage during thaw.
short rationale: Detailed timing between cold and leak; strong incident reconstruction.

Inference: Pre-emptive freeze-risk alerts from leak history
Description: Historical patterns of leaks appearing below certain temperatures allow the system to trigger pre-emptive freeze-risk alerts whenever pipes re-enter those critical temperature ranges.
short rationale: Policy/alert tuning from history; low personal impact.

Inference: Thermal safety margin estimation
Description: Comparing the temperatures at which leaks historically occur with the temperatures at which freeze alerts are configured yields a thermal safety margin, revealing whether alerts trigger early enough.
short rationale: Safety margin calculation; low privacy risk.

Inference: Differentiating freeze-prone zones from pressure-prone zones
Description: Zones with leaks mainly during cold conditions are freeze-prone, whereas zones with leaks across all temperature ranges are more likely susceptible to pressure or structural issues.
short rationale: Zone-level classification; moderate location sensitivity.

Inference: Calibration of cold-night criticality
Description: If leaks cluster in the coldest night hours when temperatures reach daily minima, those time windows are marked as critical periods requiring heightened monitoring or heating.
short rationale: Time-of-day clustering; links to occupancy schedule mildly.

Inference: Leak onset vs. temperature trend direction
Description: Leaks occurring while temperature is falling suggest contraction-related stress, whereas leaks during warming or thaw suggest failure during expansion or melting of ice.
short rationale: Trend-based cause inference; moderate incident detail.

Inference: Identifying thermally stable but leak-prone design flaws
Description: Locations with many leaks despite stable, moderate temperatures likely suffer from design or installation flaws rather than thermal problems.
short rationale: Highlights design flaws per location; moderate sensitivity.

Inference: Ranking segments by temperature-normalized leak rate
Description: Each pipe segment’s leak frequency divided by its exposure time in hazardous temperature ranges highlights segments that are intrinsically weaker or more fragile.
short rationale: Segment ranking; aggregated location insight.

Inference: Detecting under-protected external or exposed lines
Description: Segments that frequently drop below freezing and also produce more leaks than interior lines indicate under-protected or exposed piping requiring additional protection.
short rationale: Identifies exposed segments; moderate location sensitivity.

Inference: Post-repair thermal stress validation
Description: If, after leak repair, a segment experiences similar extreme temperatures as before but no longer leaks, the repair and any added insulation are withstanding previous stress levels.
short rationale: Post-repair validation with temperature context; moderate timeline/location exposure.

Inference: Identifying weak-temperature pipes
Description: Segments that start leaking at relatively mild cold temperatures, compared to others that only leak at more severe cold, are identified as structurally weaker or lower quality.
short rationale: Segment weakness identification; moderate location sensitivity.

Inference: Detecting temperature sensor misplacement via leak patterns
Description: Areas with repeated leaks but nearby temperature sensors showing little or no extreme readings suggest that temperature sensors are too far from or not thermally coupled to the actual risk zone.
short rationale: Sensor placement diagnostic using incidents; moderate location detail.

Inference: Inferring direction of cold propagation
Description: When multiple leaks follow a moving wave of low temperatures across sensors, the spatial order of leak occurrences reveals how cold stress propagates through the network.
short rationale: Propagation mapping across sensors; location/layout exposure.

Inference: Correlating leak clustering with cold spells
Description: Leak clusters that coincide with multi-day extreme cold episodes indicate that system-level leak bursts are triggered by cold spells, informing planning for peak failure periods.
short rationale: Cold-spell clustering with timelines; moderate sensitivity.

Inference: Detecting hot-spot driven leaks near heaters
Description: Leak events concentrated near sensors that record unusually high temperatures suggest overheating or local thermal hotspots as the dominant stress factor.
short rationale: Hot-spot identification; location-specific but limited personal data.

Inference: Assessing benefit of temperature alarms by leak reduction
Description: Comparing leak statistics during cold conditions before and after enabling temperature-based alarms and interventions shows whether those alarms reduce cold-related leaks.
short rationale: Aggregated impact assessment; low privacy risk.

Inference: Identifying pipes at risk from both hot and cold extremes
Description: Segments that experience both frequent hot peaks and sub-freezing dips and also show higher leak counts are under dual thermal stress and require special attention.
short rationale: Highlights dual-stress segments; moderate location sensitivity.

Inference: Understanding delayed maintenance consequences
Description: If leaks increasingly occur after multiple cold episodes over years, historical temperature and leak patterns reveal cumulative cold damage when insulation or repairs are postponed.
short rationale: Historical trend of deferred maintenance; moderate timeline exposure.

Inference: Leak likelihood conditional on current temperature
Description: Using joint history of leaks and temperature, the system can estimate the probability of a leak given the current pipe temperature, enabling temperature-aware risk scoring.
short rationale: Risk scoring from history; low personal exposure.

Inference: Segment-specific temperature thresholds
Description: Different pipe segments may show different temperature levels at which leaks historically occur, suggesting segment-specific freeze thresholds rather than a single global value.
short rationale: Segment-specific thresholds based on history; moderate location sensitivity.
